channel.title: LinkageError
channel.description:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.LinkageError: loader (instance of com/pie/jotta/util/CustomClassLoader): attempted duplicate class definition for name: "com/pie/jotta/util/command/Access"
Making a custom ClassLoader, the above error is thrown when a class is redefined. How does one redefine a class that has already been defined without said error being thrown ?

item.title: LinkageError
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

shutup nerds, the idea behind that is that the class is only unloaded when it is garbage collected. it is only garbage collected when the classloader is, so you need to use a new classloader

Read full topic

item.title: LinkageError
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:11, topic:328756”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=425150.msg3123056#msg3123056 date=1265749488]

You can always use a new classloader per class-redefinition in the worst case.

evidently you don’t understand the classloader architecture… they query their parent loaders before attempting their own, so it will return the originally loaded class and you will die.
[/quote]Evidently you don’t either.

http://tutorials.jenkov.com/java-reflection/dynamic-class-loading-reloading.html#dynamicreloading

[quote]Dynamic Class Reloading

Dynamic class reloading is a bit more challenging. Java’s builtin Class loaders always checks if a class is already loaded before loading it. Reloading the class is therefore not possible using Java’s builtin class loaders. To reload a class you will have to implement your own ClassLoader subclass.

Even with a custom subclass of ClassLoader you have a challenge. Every loaded class needs to be linked. This is done using the ClassLoader.resolve() method. This method is final, and thus cannot be overridden in your ClassLoader subclass. The resolve() method will not allow any given ClassLoader instance to link the same class twice. [/quote]
ring ring ?? afaik that complies with what i’m talking about - yes i may have been slightly and partially wrong but look at the big picture[/quote]You forgot to quote the line after that:

Therefore, everytime you want to reload a class you must use a new instance of your ClassLoader subclass.

ring ring ?? afaik that complies with what i suggested, to which you responded saying that i do not understand the classloader architecture when what i said had been correct

What you said was (partially) correct, but you were wrong in attempting to correct me.

Read full topic

item.title: LinkageError
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:8, topic:328756”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=425150.msg3122703#msg3122703 date=1265686497]

You can always use a new classloader per class-redefinition in the worst case.

evidently you don’t understand the classloader architecture… they query their parent loaders before attempting their own, so it will return the originally loaded class and you will die.
[/quote]Evidently you don’t either.

jenkov.com

Java Reflection - Dynamic Class Loading and Reloading

This text explains how to load and reload classes dynamically in Java.

Dynamic Class Reloading

Dynamic class reloading is a bit more challenging. Java’s builtin Class loaders always checks if a class is already loaded before loading it. Reloading the class is therefore not possible using Java’s builtin class loaders. To reload a class you will have to implement your own ClassLoader subclass.

Even with a custom subclass of ClassLoader you have a challenge. Every loaded class needs to be linked. This is done using the ClassLoader.resolve() method. This method is final, and thus cannot be overridden in your ClassLoader subclass. The resolve() method will not allow any given ClassLoader instance to link the same class twice.


ring ring ?? afaik that complies with what i’m talking about - yes i may have been slightly and partially wrong but look at the big picture

Read full topic

evidently you don’t understand the classloader architecture… they query their parent loaders before attempting their own, so it will return the originally loaded class and you will die.
[/quote]Evidently you don’t either.

jenkov.com

Java Reflection - Dynamic Class Loading and Reloading

This text explains how to load and reload classes dynamically in Java.

This does work, was given to be before but I couldn’t be bothered to read it in detail thus ending out in failure the first time. Upon reading it in greater detail I see the error of my ways.
